abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Financial Sector Adjustment Loan (FSAL)
            in Peru. The FSAL sought a comprehensive financial reform
            by: (a) reducing state participation in banking (by
            eliminating the development banks, curtailing activities of
            Banco de la Nacion, and privatizing state-owned commercial
            banks); (b) improving the regulation of banks (by re-casting
            banking regulations and strengthening the banking
            superintendency); and (c) reinforcing capital markets (by
            strengthening regulations and introducing a private pensions
            systems). Bank's performance was satisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned were as follows: (i) Borrower commitment is
            critical to the success of a program; (ii) design and
            implementation of a reform program is more effective when
            the relevant legislation supporting the reforms has been
            enacted; and (iii) a stable macroeconomic environment is a
            necessary condition for sustainable reforms of the financial sector.
